Description: ENERGY, MANUFACTURING AND DEPLOYMENT COSTS ARE CRITICAL TO THE VIABILITY OF ANY CARBON DIOXIDE REMOVAL APPROACH. THIS RESEARCH PROJECT FOCUSES ON A NEW STRATEGY THAT PROMISES LOW ENERGY BURDEN AND LOW MANUFACTURING COSTS TO ACHIEVE OCEAN ALKALINITY ENHANCEMENT. THE RESEARCH TEAM HAS FOUR MAIN OBJECTIVES TO TEST THIS SYSTEM AND RELATED IMPACTS. FIRST, RESEARCHERS WILL DEVELOP AND TEST A PILOT-SCALE SYSTEM THAT CAPTURES CARBON DIOXIDE FROM THE AIR AND CONVERTS IT INTO A MIXTURE OF SODIUM CARBONATE AND SODIUM BICARBONATE. THESE BYPRODUCT SALTS CAN BE USED FOR MARINE CARBON DIOXIDE REMOVAL OFFERING ADVANTAGES OVER OTHER MINERAL-BASED APPROACHES. SECOND, LABORATORY STUDIES WILL INVESTIGATE THE CHEMICAL CONSTRAINTS OF ADDING VARIOUS ALKALINE SUBSTANCES TO SEAWATER. THEY WILL EXAMINE THE PRECIPITATION OF CALCIUM CARBONATE AND BRUCITE FROM SEAWATER AND DETERMINE THE OPTIMAL RATE FOR ADDING ALKALINE SALTS TO ENSURE DISSOLUTION WITHOUT UNWANTED PRECIPITATION. THIRD, THE RESEARCHERS WILL SYNTHESI

OCEAN ALKALINITY ENHANCEMENT RELIES ON MODIFYING THE ACID-BASE PROPERTIES OF SEAWATER TO REMOVE CARBON DIOXIDE, HOWEVER THE EFFECT OF THIS STRATEGY ON PRIMARY PRODUCTIVITY, CELL PHYSIOLOGY, AND CARBON EXPORT REMAIN UNKNOWN. THESE IMPACTS ARE NOT ONLY POTENTIAL ECOSYSTEM EFFECTS, BUT MAY INFLUENCE THE EFFICIENCY OF CARBON DIOXIDE REMOVAL. THIS RESEARCH FOCUSES ON UNDERSTANDING THE IMPACTS OF OCEAN ALKALINITY ENHANCEMENT AS A METHOD OF REMOVING CARBON DIOXIDE FROM THE OCEAN ON PHYTOPLANKTON, SPECIFICALLY DIATOMS AND COCCOLITHOPHORES. UNDERSTANDING THE IMPACT OF OCEAN ALKALINITY ENHANCEMENT ON SURFACE OCEAN BIOLOGY AND ECOLOGY IS CRUCIAL FOR ITS DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION. THIS PROJECT  AIMS TO ADDRESS THESE UNCERTAINTIES BY CONDUCTING LABORATORY AND FIELD EXPERIMENTS. THE THREE OBJECTIVES OF THIS RESEARCH ARE TO FIRST CONDUCT LABORATORY EXPERIMENTS TO ASSESS THE EFFECTS OF OCEAN ALKALINITY ENHANCEMENT ON REPRESENTATIVE DIATOM AND COCCOLITHOPHORE SPECIES. RESEARCHERS EXPECT THAT SPECI

ASSESSING THE EFFICACY AND EFFICIENCY OF OCEAN ALKALINITY ENHANCEMENT ARE ESSENTIAL STEPS FOR DETERMINING THE VIABILITY AND SCALABILITY OF THIS METHOD OF CARBON DIOXIDE REMOVAL. THROUGH  PARTNERSHIP WITH A LOCAL WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT IN SAN FRANCISCO BAY, THIS PROJECT ADDS ALKALINITY TO OCEAN WATER TO REMOVE CARBON FROM THE ATMOSPHERE. RESEARCHERS WILL FIRST USE A NUMERICAL MODELING FRAMEWORK TO DESIGN THE EXPERIMENT, INCLUDING THE RELEASE STRATEGY AND A SAMPLING PLAN THAT WILL TRACK EFFECTS IN THE ENVIRONMENT. FOLLOWING THE EXPERIMENT, THE TEAM WILL CONDUCT A RETROSPECTIVE ANALYSIS THAT COMBINES MODELS AND OBSERVATIONS TO ESTIMATE THE EFFICACY OF THE ALKALINITY RELEASE IN REMOVING CARBON FROM THE ATMOSPHERE. FURTHER, THEY WILL APPLY THE MODELING FRAMEWORK TO ESTIMATE THE EFFICIENCY OF REMOVAL. THE TECHNICAL WORK WILL BE ACCOMPANIED BY PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT TO INTRODUCE LOCAL GROUPS (E.G., COMMUNITIES, TRIBES, NGOS, CIVIL SOCIETY ORGANIZATIONS) TO THE PROJECT. ENGAGEMENT WILL EXPLORE

THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO PARTNER WITH OAP TO BOLSTER PROGRAMMATIC AND GRANTS MANAGEMENT SUPPORT OF GOA-ON'S PIER2PEER SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM. OVER THE COURSE OF FIVE YEARS, 20 SCHOLARSHIPS WILL BE AWARDED AND ADMINISTERED. THE OCEAN FOUNDATION PROPOSES TO:  1. OVERSEE THE GRANT ADMINISTRATION CYCLE FOR AT LEAST TWENTY PIER2PEER SCHOLARSHIPS TO MENTOR-MENTEE PAIRS.   2. ONGOINGLY ASSESS TO ADVANCE THE APPROACHES THROUGH WHICH THE SCHOLARSHIP PROGRAM SUPPORTS RESEARCHERS WHO CAN MOST BENEFIT FROM IT.

DILGER ET AL. DESCRIBE A FIVE-DAY PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOP FOR 16 TEACHERS SERVING TITLE I MIDDLE SCHOOLS IN SANTA CLARA, CA. PARTICIPANTS WILL DEVELOP LESSON PLANS AND CULMINATE THE WEEK WITH A VISIT TO STANFORD UNIVERSITY TO MEET WITH RESEARCH SCIENTISTS. PARTICIPANTS WILL RECEIVE A STIPEND, SUPPORT FOR MATERIALS, AND MODEST COMPLETION AWARD.

DOYLE ON BEHALF OF THE FLOUR BLUFF INDEPENDENT SCHOOL DISTRICT OCEANS PROGRAM, A TITLE I SCHOOL IN TEXAS, WILL IMPLEMENT AN EDUCATION PARTNERSHIP WITH NON-COASTAL SCHOOLS TO INCREASE CAPACITY TO PROVIDE OCEAN ACIDIFICATION EDUCATION THROUGH TEACHER PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT, OCEAN ACIDIFICATION LESSON PLANS, STUDENT-LED DATA COLLECTION, CLASSROOM PARTNERSHIPS, AND ENGAGEMENT WITH OCEAN ACIDIFICATION EXPERTS.  A MINIMUM TARGET OF TEN TEACHERS FROM FOUR INLAND SCHOOLS IN ARIZONA, KANSAS, TEXAS, AND SOUTH DAKOTA WILL ATTEND VIRTUAL PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO LEARN ABOUT OCEAN ACIDIFICATION AND HOW TO IMPLEMENT NEXT GENERATION SCIENCE STANDARDS OCEAN ACIDIFICATION LESSONS IN THEIR CLASSROOMS.

ZIMMERMAN AND JOHNSON AIM TO DESIGN A GAME-BASED NEXT GENERATION SCIENCE STANDARDS (NGSS)-ALIGNED CURRICULUM THAT INTEGRATES CURRENT OCEAN ACIDIFICATION (OA) DATA AND MODELS AND FOCUSES ON SCENARIO-BASED DECISION MAKING. THE DIGITAL PROGRAM ENTITLED OCEAN PROTECTOR WILL BE ACCESSIBLE TO ANYONE WITH AN INTERNET CONNECTION AND DISTRIBUTED VIA STEAM.COM AND GITHUB. IN THIS GAME, STUDENTS ARE ASSIGNED A ROLE (FISH FARMER, SCUBA DIVER, ETC.) AND MUST MAKE DECISIONS ABOUT THE MARINE ENVIRONMENT. THE PROJECT PROVIDES TWELVE IN-PERSON DEMONSTRATIONS TO BETTER CONNECT DIVERSE STUDENT POPULATIONS IN INDIANA, AND WILL BE BETA TESTED WITH A TOTAL OF 240 MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS (GRADES 6-8). ANALYTICS WILL INFORM NOAA AND EDUCATORS HOW STUDENTS FROM INLAND COMMUNITIES ARE INTERACTING WITH AND LEARNING ABOUT OA.

FERGUSON ET AL. PROPOSE CREATING MULTIMEDIA EDUCATIONAL CONTENT AND TOOLS THAT LEAD TO HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES FOR K-12 TEACHERS IN TITLE I SCHOOLS IN THE LOS ANGELES, CA AREA. INVESTIGATORS WILL PARTNER WITH THE OCEAN AGENCY TO DEVELOP MODULES AND HOST VIRTUAL TEACHER/TEACHER TRAINER WORKSHOPS. THE PRIMARY GOALS OF THE PROJECT ARE TO FOCUS ON CREATING CULTURALLY RELEVANT MODULES ALIGNED WITH NGSS AND TO SUPPORT K-12 SCIENCE TEACHERS OF UNDERSERVED OR INLAND STUDENTS. THEY PROPOSE REACHING 40 K-12 TEACHERS, 20 FACULTY MEMBERS, 200 SCIENCE TEACHERS AND 36,000 STUDENTS.

BUSSE ET AL. PROPOSE INCREASING OCEAN LITERACY THROUGH A TWO-YEAR PROJECT TO DESIGN, DEVELOP, EVALUATE AND PROVIDE VIRTUAL HIGH SCHOOL CLASSROOM OCEAN ACIDIFICATION TOOLKITS TARGETING NON-COASTAL TITLE I HIGH SCHOOLS IN FLORIDA. THE TOOLKITS WILL INCLUDE VIRTUAL EDUCATION RESOURCES SUCH AS LESSON PLANS, DATASETS, VIDEOS, TEACHER GUIDES, BACKGROUND GUIDES, EXTENSION ACTIVITIES AND HANDS-ON SIMULATIONS FOR REACHING UP TO 1000 HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS DURING THE GRANT PERIOD. THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE STUDENTS UNDERSTANDING OF NATURAL AND ANTHROPOGENIC IMPACTS THAT CHANGE SEAWATER PH AND THE SUBLETHAL EFFECTS OF OCEAN ACIDIFICATION AND ELEVATED TEMPERATURE ON THE BEHAVIOR AND PHYSIOLOGY OF CORALS AND STONE CRAB AS TWO MODEL SPECIES. STUDENTS ALSO PRACTICE STEWARDSHIP SKILLS AS THEY WORK THROUGH THE LESSONS ON STONE CRABS AND CORAL POPULATIONS AND REPLICATE THE PROCESSES SCIENTISTS USE TO GATHER DATA.

ACIDIFICATION OF COASTAL WATERS IS OF INCREASING CONCERN TO LOCAL FISHERIES. MANY ECONOMICALLY OR ECOLOGICALLY IMPORTANT SPECIES (OYSTERS, CRABS, PHYTOPLANKTON, ZOOPLANKTON) IN THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST ARE EXPECTED TO FEEL DIRECT EFFECTS OF OCEAN ACIDIFICATION. DIRECT EFFECTS HAVE BEEN OBSERVED ON THE $100 MILLION SHELLFISH INDUSTRY, AND ADDITIONAL INDIRECT ECONOMIC IMPACTS ARE POSSIBLE ON THE FINFISH INDUSTRY DUE TO A LOSS OF PREY SPECIES. THE ABILITY TO PREDICT THE DEGREE OF ACIDIFICATION AS WELL AS RELEVANT INDICES OF IMPACT FOR SPECIES OF INTEREST COULD BE OF CONSIDERABLE BENEFIT TO MANAGERS. THE PIS PROPOSE TO ADDRESS THIS ISSUE THROUGH CONTINUED DEVELOPMENT OF AN EXISTING PREDICTION SYSTEM, CALIBRATED USING DATA FROM RELATED ELEMENTS OF THE OCEAN ACIDIFICATION PROGRAM (OAP).
